content: The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" includes provisions for improving policies related to advance directives, Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations, a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making, and increasing awareness of end-of-life planning. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include the content of advance directives in individual records and provide opportunities for discussions with trained professionals. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicare regulations to include the content of advance directives in individual records and provide opportunities for discussions with trained professionals. It also states that providers must honor valid advance directives executed outside the state to the same extent as those executed within the state, preempting any inconsistent state laws. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicaid regulations to ensure that advance directives are prominently included in an individual's medical record. It also preempts any state laws that are inconsistent with these provisions. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" amends Medicaid regulations to include advance directives in an individual's medical record and allows for discussions with a trained professional. It also states that providers must honor valid advance directives executed outside the state to the same extent as those executed within the state, preempting any inconsistent state laws. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" allows for the administration of health care treatment prohibited by state laws, preempting any inconsistent state laws. The amendments apply to provider agreements under title XVIII of the Social Security Act and State plans under title XIX, with an effective date specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The "Advance Directive Promotion Act of 2008" allows for the administration of health care treatment prohibited by state laws, with an effective date specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. State plans under title XIX may require State legislation to meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments. "Medicare covers end-of-life planning consultation during initial preventive physical examination." Medicare covers end-of-life planning consultation, which involves discussions between a physician and an individual about preparing advance directives, situations where they may be needed, the benefits of a comprehensive end-of-life plan, and resources for understanding state requirements for treatment wishes. The end-of-life plan should be updated periodically as health changes, identify resources for state requirements, including surrogate decision maker designation, and physician willingness to follow advance directives. Effective January 1, 2009, amendments apply to preventive physical examinations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a national information hotline for end-of-life decision-making and hospice care. This hotline will provide consumer information about advance directives, end-of-life planning, and available services. Additionally, there will be increased awareness of the importance of end-of-life planning through amendments to the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 399FF of Title III of the Public Health Service Act introduces programs to increase awareness of advance directive planning issues through advance directive education campaigns. The Secretary will conduct a national public education campaign to raise awareness about planning for end-of-life care, explain the importance of advance directives, and educate the public about hospice and palliative care. At least 60 percent of funds will be used for grants to public or nonprofit entities for this purpose. The Secretary will allocate 60% of funds for grants to public or nonprofit entities for conducting education campaigns on end-of-life care. Grants will be awarded for a 3-year period, with an authorization of $25,000,000 for this purpose.
